items.title: My Micro 4/3 Camera is all kitted out
items.content_text:
I have just about every accessory I would imagine I would need for my (still) new Olympus OM-D EM10 Mark III camera, and all of them, except for the little carrying case it came with and my AmazonBasics tripod, fit into this little box. I never expected to buy so many lenses in such a short time (over a 4-month period). I was having so much fun shooting photos and expanding my camera‚Äôs versatility. I tracked lens prices closely for months and bought each lens on a price dip; all in all I saved hundreds of dollars, compared to what it would have cost if I bought everything up front. Still, I spent way too much money this year on the camera; but at least I‚Äôm almost done.

To keep everything neat and tidy, rather than lumped together in a little box, I think want some kind of padded, hardshell case for everything (such as a Pelican case). I‚Äôm not sure it‚Äôs worth the expense, though, because I don‚Äôt think I would ever take it out of the house. I would continue to use the little case that came with the camera, which I love for its small size. It easily fits the camera and an extra lens or an external flash unit.

Once I sort the case situation out, I will be done with camera spending‚Ä¶at least for a few years.
Here is my obligatory Thanksgiving turkey photo.

Most of my cooking and cleaning plans today were derailed when my kitchen sink detached from the granite countertop. I was soaking oven racks in scalding hot water, which I do every year around this time, but this time the weight and the heat were too much. The sink‚Äôs seaI failed, and the sink dropped about an inch on one side. I had to bail gallons of hot water out with a bowl. Luckily, I was able to get it repaired about an hour later, but I can‚Äôt use the sink again until sometime tomorrow. At least this didn‚Äôt happen to me on Thanksgiving!
Fall

My Switch is here! But I can‚Äôt play on it yet, due to the day-job, then dinner, then bedtime, then the World Series. I‚Äôm sure I will try to play a little during the slow times during the World Series tonight.
This is a park in New Jersey that was not nearly as deserted as this photo would suggest.

The orchard called these shiny yellow apples ‚ÄúYellow Ribbon‚Äù, which is either a variety name they made up, or something that Google has not yet encountered. I think they are really Golden Delicious.
Apple picking, when it‚Äôs early enough that no one else is around.
This sort of parade happens a lot around here.

items.title: We Aren‚Äôt The Only Ones Who Like Apples
items.content_text: My family encountered a butterfly while apple-picking on Saturday.
Apple Pay is now accepted at CVS (at least my location). I‚Äôm surprised I didn‚Äôt read about this in the text press before I saw it today.
This is a Minnie toboggan, I think.
These mums, on our deck, are the only flower our deer friends have not eaten yet this week.
I liked this tree, which stands at the back of the pumpkin patch, but it was too big for me to fit into frame.
We will be returning to this pumpkin patch in about a week, I think.
Supermarket twilight
Loon Mountain, New Hampshire
New Jersey

My wife baked a delicious apple cake (yes, cake, not pie) this afternoon. We dusted it with confectioners sugar and topped it with whipped cream before serving. It was so good that my wife and daughter had seconds.
Autumn artwork with my daughter
X
Ocean Grove, New Jersey
New Jersey
New Hampshire
Partly cloudy

items.title: Mohave
items.content_text: I am upgrading my MacBook Pro to Mojave today. This is the latest into September I have waited to jump on the beta train since I started developing a Mac app several years ago. I do wish macOS upgrades were as quick and foolproof as iOS upgrades are. Last year‚Äôs upgrade nearly killed my old machine. I hope this one will work out.
New Hampshire
Community art, from a street fair in Bethlehem, New Hampshire
New Hampshire
New Hampshire

I found out that Toad the Wet Sproket re-recorded their greatest hits from the 1990s. All You Want was released in 2011. It‚Äôs unusual for a band to re-record songs in the studio (live albums are another thing entirely). I found it enjoyable to listen to, though I‚Äôm not sure why they did it. The production is more modern‚Äîread, a lot louder, but with a larger soundstage‚Äîbut the songs aren‚Äôt re-interpreted or anything.

Texas did this, too, with Texas 25, which marked their 25th anniversary as a band. Texas reinterpreted some of their songs, though. That album sounds great and is worth a listen.
I don‚Äôt remember hopscotch being drawn this way, but I‚Äôm glad my driveway has WiFi.
I tried to up my lunch game today. Note: I did not eat the entire ribeye!
üéµ I don‚Äôt always listen to ‚ÄúJosie and the Pussycats‚Äù but when I do, it‚Äôs Kay Hanley singing.
Drinking oolong tea is good, but I need to get a Red Sox mug.
A sunflower in the backyard. My daughter loves these, but we don‚Äôt admire them often enough.
Bretton Woods, New Hampshire
New Hampshire
This is the sky around my house. It‚Äôs nothing special, but will make a nice background for my iPad.

items.title: The Jersey Shore
items.content_text: I‚Äôm testing out a zoom lens I bought for my new Olympus EM-10 Mark III.

I have rarely been bothered by the iPhone 7‚Äôs (and subsequent models) lack of a headphone jack. But that was before I lost my Lightning to 3.5 mm Headphone Jack adapter. I guess I have to cough up $9 or so for a new dongle.
My family hates this picture, but I think it‚Äôs pretty cool. Look at the colors and the detail on that fly!

items.title: üéµ Vocal Jazz with the V-Moda Crossfade Wireless 2
items.content_text:
Today felt like a good day to listen to a long vocal jazz playlist through my V Moda Crossfade Wireless 2. Their warm, somewhat bass-y sound signature works surprisingly well for that genre. I mostly think of them as great for rock and pop music, but they handled sparse arrangements of vocals (male and female), piano, bass, and drums (mostly brushwork) surprisingly well.

I had to use wired mode because the Bluetooth connection is too loud for me, even at the lowest volume setting, on my iOS devices. The Bluetooth volume level appears to be more sane when I use them with my Apple TV or Mac.
My daughter and I made a new friend in the backyard today.

Apple‚Äôs Music app needs multiple selection on its playlist editor. It is tedious to remove albums I have listened to from my personal ‚Äúnew music‚Äù playlist. It is easier to manage on iTunes, but I hardly ever listen to music via my Mac anymore.
I replaced my old, crumbling, extra- extra large Grifiti wrist rest with a new one, suitably sized for my tenkeyless keyboard. It was a good move.

üéµ I‚Äôm back to my wired OPPO PM-3 & HA-2 SE headphones stack today, listening to Foreverland, by The Divine Comedy. It‚Äôs an album that slipped by me in 2016. I used to love The Divine Comedy in the late 1990s, and still take Casanova for a spin every six months or so.
Oh! I‚Äôm getting a Microsoft Office update this morning. I wonder what office suites were like in the year 2016‚Ä¶

I‚Äôm super pleased listening to these V-Moda Crossfade 2 Codex Edition headphones all day at work, over Bluetooth. (Wireless use is pretty rare for me.) Great sound. Great isolation. The top of my head is a little sore from the headband, though. (They are kind of heavy.) üéß
I found a headphone case whose brand name really gets at my peculiar affliction.

I love Assembly by Pixite. It‚Äôs an easy to use vector drawing app for iOS. Their new icon looks nice, but I will miss their cleverly designed bird icon. Luckily, it‚Äôs still on the app‚Äôs splash screen.
These Master & Dynamic MH40 headphones are something special: premium materials, crystal clear sound, wide soundstage, and a unique bump in the bass range that I like more than I thought I would.
I was finally smart enough today to bring the magnetic induction burner we never use outside to make pasta while I grilled ribeye and zucchini in the 95¬∞ heat.
I‚Äôm trying to get back on the MyFitnessPal horse today. I haven‚Äôt logged my food in six months and the results are really bad.
The mail I definitely don‚Äôt need to open right away is always convening labeled for me. They could work on the wording, though.
This inexpensive little device works just fine for microwave popcorn. It amazes me that we used that awful bagged stuff for years.
My app sales went way up this weekend, and I have no idea why. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
I am digging my old, blue, knockoff Apple Watch Sport Band again. I kind of wish I bought the real, fluoroelastomer band, though, because the silicone feels a little sticky and looks a little shiny.
My wife and I are way back in the auditorium, waiting for ‚ÄúAn Evening with Stephen Sondheim‚Äù to begin.
I‚Äôm pretty proud of my Ulysses library setup‚Äîat least the top level folder structure. My subfolders need a bit more organization, though.

While I think I want a Nintendo Switch, I‚Äôm trying to make due for now with what I already have‚Äîan iPad Pro and a SteelSeries Nimbus controller. I‚Äôm not sure I even want to commit the time to gaming, but I am curious about the latest Mario and Zelda games.
Google‚Äôs attractive but less information dense redesign of Google News may be the thing that finally breaks my addiction to it.
I decided to install some iOS games with MFi controller support on my iPad Pro. But‚Ä¶will I actually find time to play them? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

I‚Äôm making 12-bean soup today, in an effort to get back to eating home-cooked, wholesome foods. Every few months, as work and family commitments change, my family gets off track. Hopefully we can right the ship now that is is spring.

The best part of working from home is the ability to take a nice walk after lunch. Spring weather was finally here at lunchtime, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. Summer temperatures will follow by dinner time and last for the foreseeable future. So, that was spring!
I started using the Activity Digital face today. I never liked it before, but I‚Äôm trying to exercise more and it has been useful.
This is my life now.
üéß I had a lot of fun testing out the V-Moda Crossfade 2 headphones last night. My review is on Amazon.

I‚Äôm eagerly awaiting my new V-Moda Crossfade 2‚Äôs to be shipped. I want something that folds up, is durable, and sounds really good. I plan to drive them wired for serious music listening, and wireless for podcasts.

items.title: Git Tower vs. Atlassian SourceTree
items.content_text:
I am enjoying using Tower over Atlassian SourceTree. SourceTree has many, many features, and is free to use, but it has some puzzling bugs that never seem to get fixed. For example, it never deletes branches via Git Flow, no matter how many times I try to reconfigure it.

Tower is faster, works better, and has a clean UI that fits in on the Mac very well. When I emailed Tower support about something, they responded almost instantly. That sold it for me. When the Tower 3 beta expires, I will be purchasing a license.

This BeoPlay M3 speaker is a better fit in my kitchen than two feet away from me at my office desk. We got a lot of use out of it yesterday, Airplaying from iPhones and our Apple TV. It sounds better when played more loudly, in a larger room.
I deactivated by Facebook account today. I can‚Äôt muster up the gumption to delete it, and don‚Äôt know why. But it‚Äôs a start.

My current background task, while I work, is secure erasing a bunch of old, small, unneeded hard drives, to prepare them for recycling. I wish I had encrypted them, to avoid all the wait time ahead of me, but that wasn‚Äôt really an option back when I used them.

My Mac came back from the stalled OS update, but I decided to nuke the hard drive and reinstall macOS anyway. Too many little things have been broken lately. It‚Äôs the first time I have done so on this machine ever. I‚Äôve had it almost 5 years. ü§û
My son has figured out how to turn on the flashlight of my Apple Watch. No wonder battery life took a hit lately. üòÄ
Thundersnow!
Google Voice‚Äôs voicemail transcriptions can be chilling sometimes.
I actually solved a user‚Äôs problem with my iOS app today by asking ‚Äúhave you tried turning it off and on again?‚Äù üòÖ.
The light-to-dark progression in my app screenshots is oddly satisfying to me tonight.
Here we go again!
Today I am grateful for Spring Training and the return of Major League Baseball. ‚öæÔ∏è I watched two exposition games, which was fun and relaxing.
SwiftoDo 2.8.1 is now available in the App Store. It adds a Solarized Light and Solarized Dark themes, fixes bugs, and changes opening the URL menu from a long press to a slide gesture.
I would never replace my AirPods with the new ones rumored today just to upgrade them, but if I broke or lost mine, I would buy them in a second.

I learned of a service that makes RSS feeds out of Twitter users‚Äô tweets: TwitRSS.me. I added some noteworthy users to my feeds in Reeder, so I don‚Äôt miss their tweets, but also don‚Äôt have to go to Twitter to get them. Does anyone know what the best Twitter/RSS service is?
The weather was unusually warm today. I spent some of my lunch break walking outside.
Current mood.
I‚Äôm coding a nice new feature for SwiftoDo tonight. Hopefully it will be done tomorrow or Thursday, and I can get it in users hands by next weekend. Line 8 in the screenshot is new.
üéô This week‚Äôs episode had me Googling for ‚Äòlongest episode of ‚ÄúThe Talk Show‚Äù with John Gruber ever‚Äô.

I am listening to music from my MacBook Pro today, via the Oppo HA-2SE. One benefit is that it charges through its micro USB input, so playtime is unlimited. iTunes is slower and buggier than the iOS Music app, though.

Adding my Nest thermostat to HomeKit via HomeBridge has made my life a little better. I do have a suggestion for Apple, though: ‚ÄúHey Siri, set thermostat to 70¬∫ F and let no one in my family change it, ever, for any reason.‚Äù Maybe I don‚Äôt need a smart thermostat after all.
My wife baked a delicious Valentine‚Äôs Day treat. ‚ù§Ô∏èüòÑ
üéô It‚Äôs Monday morning, so I am listening to ‚ÄúThis Week in Tech‚Äù.

Replacing ‚ÄúKeyboard-‚Äú with the keyboard emoji (‚å®Ô∏è) solves a minor problem I have in the Drafts 5 beta: You can‚Äôt sort or hide action groups, and the keyboard-related groups, while useful, are not ones I open from the action groups menu. The ‚å®Ô∏è emoji sorts them below normal letters.
My wife inspired me to cook apple & sweet potato mash for my son this evening.

I have been enjoying the Roughly app‚Äôs complication (on the bottom, in the picture) for the Apple Watch. It‚Äôs a little frivolous to display the approximate time in words, but it‚Äôs also a little frivolous to use analog watch faces on a digital device.
I‚Äôm thoroughly enjoying Matt Birchler‚Äôs ‚ÄúHomePod Testing‚Äù playlist on Apple Music üéµ. Each track is well produced and interesting. It‚Äôs great music to work to.
We had a nice team dinner at Aldo‚Äôs in Baltimore last night. They have the best limoncello I‚Äôve ever had. And cannoli. And great entr√©es. üç¥
I was not thrilled that today‚Äôs New York Times mini crossword‚Äôs first word contained numbers. I didn‚Äôt know crosswords puzzles could contain numbers. It bamboozled me completely! üòÖ
People on Reddit are bitching tonight about Apple‚Äôs ‚Äúbug fixes and improvements‚Äù iOS and watchOS updates. I must be uncool or something because those kinds of updates are my favorite kind.
Oh, thank goodness for ‚òïÔ∏è. I‚Äôve got 15 minutes to down another cup before I head over to the office. It is nice to have a later start than usual today.
Baltimore‚Äôs Inner Harbor is nice. I‚Äôm glad I recognize the area in which I‚Äôm staying. My morning destination is a short walk away.
I drew and colored this under the expert tutelage of my 5-year-old daughter, just before we played together with Wellie-Wishers. üé®

Is it awful that I kind of want a HomePod? When I first watched the product announcement, my impression was ‚Äútoo expensive: hard pass‚Äù but now I kind of want something that sounds really good and just works with my iPhone.
I‚Äôm adding some very basic URL handling support to SwiftoDo tonight, based on a user request. I almost never put URLs into my task list, so I never thought to add it, but of course it makes sense.
Blog post: Eye round roast recipe
Blog post: Chicken sausage and escarole soup recipe
My wife‚Äôs and daughter‚Äôs strawberry swirl mini muffins turned out nicely, but bedtime had to be pushed back quite a bit. It‚Äôs a fair trade-off, I suppose.
This eye round roast came out magnificently, too. Am I starting a food blog now? (Is that annoying?)

My chicken sausage escarole soup came out so delicious that I‚Äôm thinking of posting my recipe. Do people still post recipes to their personal blogs? I originally did not want to start doing that again, but now I feel like I might as well.
The Crayola Experience was‚Ä¶OK, I guess. My daughter said she liked it. The rest of the day was a lot more fun, I think.

It‚Äôs a road trip day for me and my family. Picking the driving music üéµ is the hardest part. We mostly stick to Laurie Berliner Band and Hamilton. I‚Äôd love it if we could branch out more from there.
In my 20s I only drank Manhattans straight up. Now, deep into my 30s, I prefer them on the rocks‚Äîbut only when homemade. It‚Äôs been quite a week for me and now it is time to unwind. Cheers!

Every few days I have to talk myself out of buying another pair of headphones. I don‚Äôt need the HifiMan HE-400i, and their sound leakage probably wouldn‚Äôt suit my listening needs at all, but I can‚Äôt stop thinking about adding an open-backed headphone to my meager collection.
I submitted a new SwiftoDo build to the App Store for a ‚ÄúBug Fixes and Performance Improvements‚Äù update. Now I can move on to more important things.

items.title: Ready Player One
items.content_text: I just finished Ready Player One by Ernest Cline üìö . It was light and enjoyable the whole way through. I‚Äôm not sure just how much I liked it, as reading it was a little like watching somebody else play video games, which is not really my thing, but I did like it. I‚Äôm glad the author addressed the isolation of all the main characters in real life, at least a little. It could have had more depth in that area, but that might have diminished its charm.
The dining room is looking better now, too. I can‚Äôt believe we didn‚Äôt put anything up on that wall for 7 years.
I posted some photos I took in my son‚Äôs room. I hope he likes flowers. (He‚Äôs a baby.)
I am lazily cooking salsa chicken thighs for either lunch or dinner.
I don‚Äôt even wish I was actually this good at solving The New York Times Mini Crossword Puzzle.

My prediction for ‚ÄúThe Good Place‚Äù series finale (which hopefully will be several years from now): The whole thing is Michael‚Äôs ‚ÄúBad Place‚Äù. He‚Äôs the one being tortured. Holy forking shirt balls!
It happened slowly, but preferred music playback device size and wire count have gone up for me over time. 2010: iPod Shuffle. 2017: iPad Air 2 & Oppo HA2-SE.

Dear Apple Music: Just because I listened to Sixpence Non The Richer‚Äôs cover of ‚ÄúThere She Goes‚Äù (originally by the La‚Äôs, and arguably about heroin, for goodness sake), doesn‚Äôt mean I want to listen to Christian music in all my personalized mixes. üôÑ

So far the snowfall hasn‚Äôt been so bad‚Äîonly a few inches so far. It is windy, though, and very cold. My daughter, home on a snow day, is watching ‚ÄúFrozen‚Äù, which is apt. I am turning my attention to hot tea and (less hot) database programming.

We are bracing for a blizzard tonight, which is expected to snow us in all day tomorrow. School is canceled already. (Work isn‚Äôt.) I feel like it is a metaphor for what‚Äôs going on in my life right now. (Photo is historical.)
We are at my neighbors‚Äô house for a simulated 7:30 PM ball drop. Fun NYE party!
My daughter‚Äôs cookie decorating skills are advancing! I‚Äôm so proud of her. üòÄüç™
It was a really close game!
I made banana bread, too.
I baked Snickerdoodles for the family today. They are really, really good!
